conclusion: Consider the geometric configuration and properties of light in the medium.
The triangle ABC has side length L, BD = L/4, and the hemisphere has a radius R = L/2.
The light enters the hemisphere at point D on AB.
The longest path within the hemisphere would be when the light refracts and travels along the largest possible internal path.
The critical path for the light would be perpendicular to the incident direction.
The maximum internal path would be along the diameter of the hemisphere.
The length of the internal path is the diameter of the hemisphere, which is L.
Let v be the speed of light in the medium, and c be the speed of light in vacuum. Refractive index n = c/v.
The time t taken for light to travel a distance d in a medium is t = d/v.
For the longest path d = L.
The propagation time t is given by t = L/v = L/(c/n) = (L * n)/c.
The longest propagation time of refracted light in the hemisphere is (L * n)/c.
